articles.headline: ABC Rejects Dual Anchors in 2nd Shuffle
articles.snippet: Charles Gibson will replace Elizabeth Vargas less than six months after she and Bob Woodruff became co-anchors.
articles.abstract: Charles Gibson will replace Elizabeth Vargas less than six months after she and Bob Woodruff became co-anchors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than six months after naming Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff over Charles Gibson as the successors to the late Peter Jennings on "World News Tonight" on ABC, the network announced yesterday that it was scrapping its dual-host experiment and installing Mr. Gibson as the sole anchor.

articles.headline: U.S. Plan to Lure Nurses May Hurt Poor Nations
articles.snippet: The Senate immigration bill would throw open the gate to nurses and, some fear, drain them from developing countries.
articles.abstract: The Senate immigration bill would throw open the gate to nurses and, some fear, drain them from developing countries.

articles.headline: The Plane That Won't Die
articles.snippet: The C-17 Globemaster III cargo jet, a $200 million flying giant, is at the center of a war involving the White House, the Pentagon, Boeing and lobbyists.
articles.abstract: The C-17 Globemaster III cargo jet, a $200 million flying giant, is at the center of a war involving the White House, the Pentagon, Boeing and lobbyists.

articles.headline: Philadelphia Investors Buy Two Newspapers
articles.snippet: The $562 million sale of the Inquirer and Daily News ends a chapter of uncertainty and turmoil at the papers.
articles.abstract: The $562 million sale of the Inquirer and Daily News ends a chapter of uncertainty and turmoil at the papers.

articles.snippet: The Home Depot board has awarded its chief executive $245 million in his five years with the company.
articles.abstract: The Home Depot board has awarded its chief executive $245 million in his five years with the company.

articles.headline: Regulators Denounce Fannie Mae
articles.snippet: The report from a 27-month investigation details the manipulation of earnings and the creation of an "unethical and arrogant culture" at the top.
articles.abstract: The report from a 27-month investigation details the manipulation of earnings and the creation of an "unethical and arrogant culture" at the top.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators said yesterday that financial results at Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of mortgages, were "illusions deliberately and systematically" created by its top executives in an $11 billion accounting scandal.

articles.headline: This Glass Is Half Full, Probably More

articles.abstract: Many Democratic politicians just don't seem comfortable talking about the ways that overall living standards have risen.

articles.headline: This Glass Is Half Full, Probably More
articles.snippet: HERE is a political Rorschach test for this midterm election year. What's your reaction to the following:     These are the best of times in many ways. Americans are wealthier than previous generations, they are healthier and they enjoy a higher s...
articles.abstract: HERE is a political Rorschach test for this midterm election year. What's your reaction to the following:     These are the best of times in many ways. Americans are wealthier than previous generations, they are healthier and they enjoy a higher standard of living. The good old days simply weren't as good as the present day.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - HERE is a political Rorschach test for this midterm election year. What's your reaction to the following:

articles.headline: Regulators Denounce Fannie Mae
articles.snippet: Federal regulators said yesterday that financial results at Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of mortgages, were ''illusions deliberately and systematically'' created by its top executives in an $11 billion accounting scandal.     The finding...
articles.abstract: Federal regulators said yesterday that financial results at Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of mortgages, were ''illusions deliberately and systematically'' created by its top executives in an $11 billion accounting scandal.     The finding was in a blistering report by the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, or Ofheo, after a 27-month investigation into Fannie Mae's corporate culture and accounting practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators said yesterday that financial results at Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of mortgages, were "illusions deliberately and systematically" created by its top executives in an $11 billion accounting scandal.

articles.headline: Armed Groups Propel Iraq Toward Chaos
articles.snippet: Even in a country beset by murder and death, the 16th Brigade represented a new frontier.     The brigade, a 1,000-man force set up by Iraq's Ministry of Defense in early 2005, was charged with guarding a stretch of oil pipeline that ran through t...
articles.abstract: Even in a country beset by murder and death, the 16th Brigade represented a new frontier.     The brigade, a 1,000-man force set up by Iraq's Ministry of Defense in early 2005, was charged with guarding a stretch of oil pipeline that ran through the southern Baghdad neighborhood of Dawra. Heavily armed and lightly supervised, some members of the largely Sunni brigade transformed themselves into a death squad, cooperating with insurgents and executing government collaborators, Iraqi officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 23 - Even in a country beset by murder and death, the 16th Brigade represented a new frontier.

articles.headline: ABC Rejects Dual Anchors in 2nd Shuffle
articles.snippet: Less than six months after naming Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff over Charles Gibson as the successors to the late Peter Jennings on ''World News Tonight'' on ABC, the network announced yesterday that it was scrapping its dual-host experiment a...
articles.abstract: Less than six months after naming Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff over Charles Gibson as the successors to the late Peter Jennings on ''World News Tonight'' on ABC, the network announced yesterday that it was scrapping its dual-host experiment and installing Mr. Gibson as the sole anchor.     ABC's move comes after Mr. Woodruff was seriously injured by a roadside bomb in Iraq in late January, sustaining head wounds that have since kept him from appearing on television, and after Ms. Vargas announced in February that she was due to give birth to her second child in mid-August.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than six months after naming Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff over Charles Gibson as the successors to the late Peter Jennings on "World News Tonight" on ABC, the network announced yesterday that it was scrapping its dual-host experiment and installing Mr. Gibson as the sole anchor.

articles.headline: With Links to Board, Chief Saw His Pay Soar
articles.snippet: Every October, some 50 former Home Depot managers, calling themselves the Former Orange-Blooded Executives, after the home-improvement chain's trademark bright orange color, gather in Atlanta to reminisce, chat about new jobs and pass around pictu...
articles.abstract: Every October, some 50 former Home Depot managers, calling themselves the Former Orange-Blooded Executives, after the home-improvement chain's trademark bright orange color, gather in Atlanta to reminisce, chat about new jobs and pass around pictures of their children.     The discussion inevitably turns to the changes at Home Depot under its chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli. A growing source of resentment among some is Mr. Nardelli's pay package. The Home Depot board has awarded him $245 million in his five years there. Yet during that time, the company's stock has slid 12 percent while shares of its archrival, Lowe's, have climbed 173 percent.

articles.headline: Fed Chief Swears Off Improvising
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve, is likely to be a lot less interesting at dinner parties from now on.     On Tuesday, not quite four months after taking over at the Fed, Mr. Bernanke publicly admitted to a ''lapse of judg...
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve, is likely to be a lot less interesting at dinner parties from now on.     On Tuesday, not quite four months after taking over at the Fed, Mr. Bernanke publicly admitted to a ''lapse of judgment'' in earlier telling a television reporter at a banquet here that investors had ''misunderstood'' him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23 - Ben S. Bernanke, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve, is likely to be a lot less interesting at dinner parties from now on.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Raid Divides G.O.P. Lawmakers and White House
articles.snippet: After years of quietly acceding to the Bush administration's assertions of executive power, the Republican-led Congress hit a limit this weekend.     Resentment boiled among senior Republicans for a second day on Tuesday after a team of warrant-be...
articles.abstract: After years of quietly acceding to the Bush administration's assertions of executive power, the Republican-led Congress hit a limit this weekend.     Resentment boiled among senior Republicans for a second day on Tuesday after a team of warrant-bearing agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation turned up at a closed House office building on Saturday evening, demanded entry to the office of a lawmaker and spent the night going through his files.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 23 - After years of quietly acceding to the Bush administration's assertions of executive power, the Republican-led Congress hit a limit this weekend.

articles.headline: Philadelphia Investors Buy Two Newspapers
articles.snippet: A group of local investors bought The Philadelphia Inquirer and its sister paper, The Daily News, yesterday, promising not to interfere with news-gathering operations, although critics question whether editorial independence will be possible.     ...
articles.abstract: A group of local investors bought The Philadelphia Inquirer and its sister paper, The Daily News, yesterday, promising not to interfere with news-gathering operations, although critics question whether editorial independence will be possible.     The new owners paid the McClatchy Company $562 million for the papers, and said they would keep publishing The Daily News, a tabloid with a declining circulation whose future has periodically been in doubt. And they pledged not to interfere in the running of the newspapers, addressing concerns that the papers might cater to their business interests.

articles.headline: The Plane That Won't Die
articles.snippet: In January, Nancy Reagan went to the California desert for a dedication ceremony to honor her husband. The Air Force was naming a new C-17 cargo plane the ''Spirit of Ronald Reagan.''      She greeted the crowds, but did not speak. Instead, she is...
articles.abstract: In January, Nancy Reagan went to the California desert for a dedication ceremony to honor her husband. The Air Force was naming a new C-17 cargo plane the ''Spirit of Ronald Reagan.''      She greeted the crowds, but did not speak. Instead, she issued a statement saying that the late president ''would be pleased'' that the plane would provide support for ''our troops fighting in faraway lands.'' Officials at the event offered their tributes to the plane, and talked about its essential role in fighting wars.
